Reviews.Title: Okay system for interior monitoring - Not too ideal for outside applications where exposure to elements is unavoidable -
Reviews.Author: finaldraft151
Reviews.Content: Disclaimer: Most of the reviews seem to knock this down in rating based upon the difficulty to access the remote viewing feature and nightmares with network/internet compatibility as well as lack of customer support. While these are all valid factors, they didn't influence my rating and following review since I do not need the remote viewing feature nor will I need to link it to my network/router, etc -This review is for the folks (like me) that just want to be able to monitor/record interior/exterior areas of their house, business, etc with the ability to review the recorded footage at a later time should something get vandalized, stolen, etc. during the night, over the weekend, or for monitoring who's coming and going at the door, porch, mailbox -  You get the idea.I'm not an IT person, don't have an extensive background in computers or the surveillance industry - However, like most people I can use a PC, DVR, Smartphone and update my Facebook status without relying on help from a digital/tech savvy 10 year old -  so if that's you too, relax. -  Anyone that knows the difference between a pair of pliers and a crescent wrench will have no problems setting this up for basic monitoring/recording. It's like hanging up Christmas lights for me by now, as this is system #5 on a new property. After doing a temp set up using previous hardware already in place this is my take on this unit that will hopefully help out some folks and assist them in determining if it's right for their house and needs.This system is easy to set up, it delivers an okay and acceptable image and is ideal for the homeowner or small business owner. (again I'm referring to only the installation of the cameras & hooking up to your TV or computer monitor and recording/reviewing footage with the included DVR - NOT THE REMOTE ACCESS - WIFI - NETWORK/INTERNET Capabilities) -While this system is marketed as a indoor and OUTDOOR system,  it's definitely not designed with an emphasis on the outdoors, longevity wise, as the elements of even living in cookie cutter suburbia will reduce the lives of the cameras and wiring substantially from my experience with similar units. I've installed 4 surveillance systems on my home over the past 20 years and I was not that impressed with the quality of the wiring and the fact that the camera and power connectors aren't hardwired into the camera (you connect the camera to it's video and power cable at the mounting spot as opposed to just a single wire that is hardwired right into the camera and then powered by the monitor inside your home) - That is an automatic drawback.BNC and a power cable at the camera location? Exterior? Aside from the highly noticeable red and yellow plastic connectors that scream attention to themselves, this type of setup is a disaster in the elements - Within a few months rest assured that the sun, exposure to wind, rain and just the elements will have these frayed & destroyed - One could build a 'makeshift' box to protect the connectors, but that's more time and aggravation. I learned the hard way with an identical setup and know that this is a recipe for a camera failure a few months down the road - Even if you're mounting under eaves or in a place that isn't directly exposed to sun, wind, etc - You have to deal with securing and concealing the wiring. Depending on your house, it may or may not be that big of an issue - For this house, it is an issue since my eaves are not that high, and if one wanted they could just rip the camera and wiring off quite easily.IMAGE: Not bad. Okay and well within an acceptable quality range for the price. Night vision is fairly good - Remember, these aren't going to be able to read plates in pitch black night from 100 feet away - It does a good enough job at close range, but ambient light from a porch light, street light, etc improves it - In all fairness the image quality is good for what you're paying for. Don't have unrealistic expectations that it's going to capture crystal clear images from great distances - But it will catch a good image of a person in your driveway within 20 feet or so in near dark conditions.IMAGE SIZE - That left me unimpressed - I felt as if the cameras are all zoomed in - The best way to describe it: Imagine a mid 1990's camcorder on max zoom on a person or object from a considerable distance - Basically the aspect ratio is not wide enough for my needs - (older bullet IR cameras I am replacing had 3x the width) These are great for smaller/confined areas (like the porch, a door, gate) but forget a wide area - The image is good but too 'close' -Wiring/cables: Like others,  I did find them to be rather thin - Which wouldn't be an issue if I was using them indoors - These wires definitely wouldn't survive one summer without degrading under the hot sun. If you can install them where they won't be exposed to the sun for long periods you should be fine, but for anyone that needs to run them in areas where they will get a lot of exposure - I'd be leery -DVR: It's great and easy to configure - No problems with that - Remote and mouse all work as described - No issues there.PROS: Inexpensive and quick set up - For the money it is a good deal if it fits your needs - Basically something that you can install quickly and have up and running and won't loose sleep over if you can't take it with you if you move.CONS: BNC and Power connectors at the camera; BAD for exterior application - Makes it vulnerable to the elements, calls attention to itself and is one more thing you have to secure and (if needed) conceal.Mounts are standard cheap metal mounts that do the job - Screws are almost a bad joke - Plan on using decent ones if you want it to stay in place - The supplied screws are about as durable as scotch tape on a hot stove -In closing - After testing the cameras, DVR and reviewing footage from day/night recording I'm not all that impressed. I'm not unhappy, but I thought that the camera image quality was identical to something from 15 years ago - Not 2014. They're great for now, don't get me wrong, but I foresee them fizzling/dying out in 6-12 months.  Had I made the mistake of permanently mounting them, running the cable through eaves, attics and crawlspaces, well I'd keep it and make the best of them - But I'm relieved  I only did a temporary set up for testing and evaluation.I WOULD KEEP THEM and do a full permanent installation if the cameras were hardwired with video/power cable - The deal breaker is the ridiculous BNC and power cable plug at the mounting location that one must plug into the camera. Had these been hardwired, I'd be content to keep them - I can deal with everything else, pro/con but from experience, the BNC and power plug at the camera is a no go for me. Other than that, I see no other negatives worthy of noting - I just feel this is better suited for indoors with the way it's video and power line is set up - Thin wire + Connectors at the camera makes this a dud for my house.Now of course that's just my evaluation based upon the set up at my house - Do your homework and get an idea of where you will mount these and note how much wire will have to be ran and secured - They may be ideal or impractical - It all depends on your needs and where you install them.

Reviews.Title: matches my needs
Reviews.Author: bigd
Reviews.Content: the reviews are correct, but thanks to diligent research on my part, these cameras fit exactly what i needed.  i work from home and wanted some "eyes in the sky" to see vehicles/people approach my house.  as a bonus, this kit comes with 4 cameras so for kicks i can watch my back yard too.if you're trying to catch a criminal in the act, these are the WRONG choice.  you need high end, crystal clear.  these are simple video cameras, they'll catch a person or car during the day.  night vision barely works.. it may catch someone roaming your yard if they're wearing all white clothing.  at least that's my experience.the cables are cheap.  they work, but they're not shielded enough.  my video image has some light static, similar to an old VHS tape where you can adjust with tracking.  i'm not complaining about this, the video does the job and i'll upgrade the cables on my own.  any electronics will do this with too much electrical in close proximity as i definitely have in my office.THE INSTRUCTION MANUAL IS DEFINITELY LAUGHABLE.  i'm a senior network engineer for one of the top 3 largest software companies in the world and even i find this instruction manual useless.  i tossed it and decided to plug them in locally (in my lap) and test everything on my own before wiring permanently.  they worked, but tinkering with the DVR is going to be some serious trial and error.  networking won't be a problem for me, but i salute anyone with no networking experience attempting it.  i was tempted to return this product on behalf of this manual alone.  i can tell you without a doubt, this manual is an engineer's guide.  likely handed to Zmobod's new hires.  it doesn't explain anything, instead just a step-by-step walkthru to get from point A to point B when there's no time to explain what it is.  engineers use this type of thing daily, but if Zmodo was worth anything they'd send this booklet to a TECHNICAL WRITER to expand on it and add some useful flow to an average end-user.  it's quite pathetic.  words are misspelled, run-on and incomplete sentences, mismatching font sizes.  really b-rated garbage.  whoever made it didn't care and i couldn't help but think the product must have been made with the same lack thereof.i gave in, hooked it up, and i'm satisfied with it.  for the price, it's not in the cheap useless category and the next price up gets into expensive range for me.  they do the job, no telling if they break in 6 months, but i'm fine with the risk for the price ratio.  so far so good for me.again, if you need to identify people or "license plates" (seriously?) then this is not for you.  perhaps you should call NSA and borrow some satellite time b/c you are going to spend gobs for that kind of setup.  for simple eyes in the yard, no intent on catching anything (but bonus if you do), don't expect useful quality to hand over to law enforcement, but it can confirm the event happened and possibly pick up a car or clothing or other nonsense that will likely never be caught by authorities anyway.  watching the yard for kids playing, spouse in the garden, delivery truck arriving, sketchy door-to-door salesmen (why i purchased), the product is outstanding.  love it so far, minus the garbage documentation.hope this helps.

Reviews.Content: Fairly easy to set-up. Had video streaming to my phone in no time. Set-up DVR motion sensing recording with little effort. The cameras included get very good face shots out to about fifteen-twenty feet in light (if you know the person maybe out to twenty five to thirty feet), at night I'd say five-ten feet (if you know the person I'd say maybe out to fifteen to twenty max).Second, the interface and configuration options while connected over your network do not come close to what you can do hooking a monitor and mouse up to the DVR directly. This sucks because if you hide your DVR, as you should for security purposes, you have to dig it out, unlock it, whatever, in order to hook a monitor and mouse up to it to do whatever administrative tasks you need to do. It is not the end of the world, but it would be much better if the network interface allowed complete control.I would buy another for a second house or business.Update: Back up the cameras with motion sensing lights for night time use. I had my Jeep broken into and my motorcycle stolen, which were both caught on camera at night in my driveway. The video was not clear enough to see faces in either case (the thief's face that broke into the Jeep was about ten feet from the camera and it was not clear enough to give 100% mugshot surety). You can see what is happening, what clothes people are wearing and even their ethnicity, but detail is not that good (i.e. you will not get a good mugshot at all).I would still buy this setup again -- but if I need very good clarity at night in a certain area I would add light or upgrade that camera. I am adding wireless, motion sensing lights to the system and now will be able to see everything at night. I also ordered motion sensing alerts to the driveway, so if someone goes into that area it will sound a signal to a portable, remote alarm. I am tired of just watching videos -- time to apprehend the thieves and post those videos on YouTube.

Reviews.Title: Unbelievably complex remote set up
Reviews.Author: SFOHINTL "Tru"
Reviews.Content: This is one of the most useful but frustrating products I've ever bought. When it's all done it's a wonderful extra set of eyes on your property and gives peace of mind that you can check in from anywhere in the world to see it.Getting there, though, was not easy. The many tutorials and remote set up instructions simply did not work. I have a PC (with IE10), Mac, Android, iPad and iPhone in this household. Tried the simplest connection first - locally via the router - only to find you cannot connect to the DVR with either IE10 or a Mac. Must be a PC with IE9 or before. So I went through the remote set up instructions with painstaking attention to detail. I got the ports on my router forwarded and confirmed they were open. I got the right IP address settings, set up the DDNS redirect and none of my mobile devices would connect to the thing. What finally worked is I deleted all of the usernames on the device and replaced them with lowercase options and simple 4-digit passcodes. Reviews.Title: Very basic system but you can do much better.
Reviews.Author: jray
Reviews.Content: I bought this about a month or so ago and I would not recommend it unless this is all your budget can afford.The night vision is very poor.The day camera quality is marginal at best.I returned this after seeing the quality. Instead I opted for a QSEE 720P camera system with 1 TB DVR. The cost was about 2.5x more but here is the advantages (and I am not advocating for QSEE over ZMODO). First off if you are going to spend the time running the wires and installing the cameras then spending more for better is a no brainer. The QSEE 720p cameras have a wider angle, super clear picture and excellent night vision. I found the ZMOMO system had very low quality made 60ft pnc cables while the QSEE system had 100ft quality POE ethernet cable (Power over ethernet) so still only a single line run to each camera. The Zmodo dvr interface was ancient comared to the QSEE dvr. The QSEE system I bought came with 4 720p cameras (which appear to be rebranded Dahua IPC-HFW2100 cameras which run $150 apiece). I paid $499 for the QSEE system and have had it running for about a month with no issues even in sub zero weather.Running the cable for any system will take a lot of time but 720p is such an upgrade over the tvl cameras its shouldn't even be a decision. I give this system 2 stars based on cost. Having cameras will deter people but having usable video at longer distances is not possible without better cameras. The plus about the POE systems is that if you want to upgrade the wiring is in place. You cant upgade to good cameras with the bnc wiring without replacing it.Bottom line is if its within your budget go with a 720p system or better (better being 1080p cameras). Doing the wiring for any system is a task. It took me two hours to run all the cable and set up two cameras outside (planning ahead is key). I bought a keystone wall plate and couplers to connect everything so the installation was clean (and the wiring is already there to connect the other cameras). My installation I would consider on the easier side just based on where I located the dvr and the run to the attic. Again the install is a one time task but will take time so make sure the system you buy will meet your expectations in the end.

Reviews.Title: Bad Buy
Reviews.Author: ACD
Reviews.Content: If you're truly concerned with security at your home or small office, this is a bad buy and a waste of your hard earned money. The system itself performs as its supposed to: it will record and capture video and you can access it on the network to look at a live view.But consider this: this is a reactive approach to security. If someone steals your valuables and you have it recorded on video, what then? You can turn it into the police, but unless they have a crystal clear image of the individual(s) and that person is a known criminal in their system or you can identify them, then you are SOL. In other words, file an insurance claim and hope for the best, because the police can't do anything.Did you know that video surveillance isn't admissible in court as evidence unless it can be identified by a witness? That means you had to either be watching them steal your valuables on your phone while this was happening or someone at the location of the crime witnessed the act while the video was recording and can testify to the matter. This system will really offer you 0 value unless you intend to use it to monitor employee behavior. I would highly recommend investing in an alarm service or video monitoring service, or hiring a consultant to provide details on how to make your home or office more secure (such as adding lighting or building a fence). Unfortunately I have learned from experience.
